data.title: Our team
data.meta_description: The SAS team is a mix of water lovers of all sorts, with a passion for the ocean, and an unquenchable drive to protect it and all it makes possible.
data.text:
Giles Bristow, CEO, RNLI crew, and luckiest person alive

I joined this outstanding team in 2023 and could not be more impressed by their passion and ability to campaign and work for a thriving ocean and thriving people.

I made my way to SAS via a career as an environmental lawyer and then working at a senior level in environmental NGOs in climate & energy, food, and marine systems. I am in love with the ocean and share my passion for swimming, sailing, wing-foiling, and surfing with the crew at SAS, friends, and my wife and daughters. I feel incredibly fortunate that I work for the ocean.

Being RNLI crew in Lyme Regis, I may need to run if my pager sounds.

I’m a wild swimmer, stand-up paddleboarder, and rockpool gazer, with a deep love of nature and our blue spaces, both inland and coastal.

I am so excited to be joining Surfers Against Sewage at this pivotal moment when we need to keep up the pressure on polluters and governments, and press for the changes we need.

I joined SAS in November 2022 and as the Financial Director I am responsible for ensuring the finances of the charity run smoothly.

My love of the ocean started at a young age when I used to go dinghy sailing. In my 20s I sailed across the Atlantic and the beauty and vitality of the ocean has stuck with me ever since! These experiences motivate me to help protect it for the future.

Adriana Ciontea (she/her) – Communications Officer

David Attenborough, nature and ocean activist extraordinaire, said that “Saving our planet is now a communications challenge. We know what to do, we just need the will.”

Fuelled by my passion for words and the ocean, I joined SAS in August 2022 as a Communications Officer. I oversee our social media channels, and love to inspire and connect with other ocean activists.

I only surf the bookish/watery corners of the internet (for now).

Aloha, I’m Yvette. I joined SAS in May 2023 as the Equality, Diversity and Inclusion Manager. I have spent several years campaigning for blue spaces (any open water) to be a more diverse and equitable place and I am so very happy that I now get to work on amplifying voices from all communities to help protect the blue spaces we love and encourage more people to engage with them.

I love spending time in the ocean, or anywhere, with my partner, 3 children and 2 dogs and of course the many amazing women and girls we surf with at Wave Wahines.

I joined SAS in July 2023 as their Senior Fundraising Data Development Officer. You’ll find me diving into all things data and systems within our fundraising team to enable more Ocean saving work!

I love the Ocean. And data! So I’m thrilled to part of a Surfers Against Sewage, campaigning and taking action. Although – you won’t catch me surfing any waves – just enjoying the beauty of them!

Chloe Flood – Campaigns Officer

Pronouns: She/Her

I joined SAS in January 2023 as the Campaigns and Policy Coordinator and have recently moved into the role of Campaigns Officer. I help support the delivery of all of our ocean saving campaigns and activations!

I have always felt connected to the ocean. Whether it’s a coastal walk, a quick dip, a snorkel or an attempt at surfing, I am my happiest by the sea!

Emily van de Geer (she/her) – Philanthropy & Partnerships Manager

I joined SAS in January 2019 and after 4 years leading on our education work I now look after our Philanthropy and Partnerships team.

My role involves, securing funding for our work through Trusts & Foundations, and working with the philanthropists and businesses who support us.

I’ve spent almost a decade working to protect the ocean. When I’m not in the office, you’ll find me in or by the sea.

I joined SAS in January 2024 as the Executive Assistant supporting the CEO, Trustees and Leadership team in all matters governance. I feel incredibly privileged to be working with such an amazing team doing incredible campaign work protecting the ocean.

I swim in the sea every morning before work and whenever else I can, it resets my soul and reminds me how lucky I am to live and work in Cornwall.

Emma O’Neill (She/her)

Before coming to SAS I worked in the marine mammal rescue field for over 10 years, and have seen the devastating impacts of pollution on our marine life here in Cornwall. It has led me to be passionate about reducing our reliance on single-use plastics, so I was thrilled to join SAS as Communities Officer for Plastic Free Communities in Jan 2023. I support a network of volunteers in the UK, all working to tackle avoidable single-use plastics in their own communities. I love spending time with my family and crazy spaniel around the Cornish coast, and never pass off a chance to jump in the sea!

Emma Piper (she/her) – Operations Officer

Hola! I joined SAS in May 2022 and love looking after the office and everyone in it. Heading up our Net Zero Project as well as diving into IT, supplier due diligence and Health & Safety are just the tip of the iceberg for my role, ensuring no two days are the same!

I am working to protect the ocean as I adore the world’s aquatic wildlife, and want to help keep them safe from present day dangers.

Hello!

I joined SAS in April 2023 as the Science and Research Officer. I am a freshwater ecologist by background, having recently finished my PhD in river health in late 2022. Now, I coordinate water quality research at SAS, in both the marine and freshwater space. I usually have my feet firmly planted in Celtic waters, whether that’s the rivers of Wales or the waves of the South West, and I am so happy to be here driving effective science-backed campaigns to help protect them.

Franka Fueller (she/her) – Head of Public Fundraising

I joined SAS in the summer of 2019 to grow our income and fund our ocean saving work. My job involves leading a talented and passionate team to create campaigns and communications that inspire people to fundraise and donate.

I’m here because the ocean needs help and wonderful people like you want to help – and connecting the two creates real change that I’m incredibly proud to be part of.

Hello,

I originally joined SAS in 2020 and after taking a year out for an extended surf adventure re-joined in 2023 as Policy and Research Manager.

I’m working with a great team to convince politicians all over the UK to deliver research and evidenced policy solutions to tackle pollution and climate change.

I’m based up in Scotland and if I’m not surfing I’ll be up a munro.

Jacey Price (she/her) – Senior Database Officer

I joined SAS way back in 2016 and during that time my role has evolved into what it is today, which is all things data!

I grew up in Cornwall and have always been lucky enough to live by the sea, which inspires me to work hard to protect it.

Jade Chapman (She/her)

Communications Officer

Hey! I joined Surfers Against Sewage in April 2021.

I work in communications and handle our email campaigns and media. I’m essentially a professional keyboard warrior, and I love it. If you get our monthly newsletter, thanks, that’s from me!

I’m here because I want to give nature the chance to thrive, and fighting the good fight with SAS puts me, and the ocean, in good stead. From one ocean lover to another, I hope you stick around!

Josh Harris (he/him) – Head of Communications

I’ve been at SAS since moving back home to Cornwall in early 2021. My role is focused on ensuring that all our communications motivate audiences to engage in Ocean Activism, in whatever way fits their preference.

Growing up in Penzance, I’ve always felt a deep connection with the sea and coastal communities so I feel deeply privileged to be able to spend my working life protecting the ocean.

I joined Surfers Against Sewage as an HR Officer in January 2023. This is a new role in the ever growing SAS and I am happy to be part of that journey – exciting times!

I am thrilled to not only work for a charity I believe is extremely important to everyone, but also with a team of people that are committed and passionate about the sea and the climate.

I have just returned to Cornwall, left for 9 months and missed it so much. I even missed swimming in the sea when its freezing, walking on the cliffs when it’s gale force winds 😊 and I am never leaving again!!

Kirsty Davies (she/her) – Community Water Quality Manager.

I joined SAS in March 2022 in a role to improve the water quality of our inland waterways. I feel privileged to work with passionate communities across the UK who are applying for bathing water designation.

Like for many people the water is my happy place. Ensuring the water quality of our rivers, seas and lakes are monitored and protected for people to enjoy and nature to thrive, is what drives me in my role at SAS.

Lara Jeffries (she/her) – Education Manager

I joined SAS in May 2023 following a career in education, as a teaching assistant, teacher and Headteacher.

I work with an incredible Education Team, whose goal it is to develop Ocean Activists and build Ocean Literacy through educational resources, events and activities. We also run the Plastic Free Schools accreditation programme, which empowers pupils to reduce plastic in their school communities. In addition, we offer teacher training to support the delivery of Plastic Free Schools.

I love the ocean…if I am not in it, I am enjoying being near it.

Laura Macey (she/her) – Senior Education Officer

Hey! I joined SAS in January 2021 and work in the Education Team.

My role involves designing and delivering programmes that inspire and empower young people to join our ever-growing network of ocean activists.

Having been lucky enough to grow up in Cornwall with the beach as my playground, the ocean has become part of who I am. So when I’m not surfing, swimming or generally frolicking in the sea, I’m fighting to protect it.

Lizzie Cresswell, Community Water Quality Officer, she/her

I joined SAS in July 2021 armed with an entrenched belief that protecting the ocean is the Most Important Thing. (Still true.) As part of the fundraising team, I look after our incredible members, donors and legacy-leavers – and help raise ocean-saving funds. Since that July, my love of the ocean has only grown. My surfing ability, however, has not.

My life has revolved around the Ocean, in the UK, Canada and South America and there’s nothing that makes me happier than surf and sunsets over the sea. I’ve worked with communities in humanitarian, conservation and activism settings and I am stoked to be supporting the amazing communites of Surfers Against Sewage. It’s a privilege to be working with Ocean Activists from all over the UK, supporting them to positive create change in their communities and working hard to make sure Ocean Activism is an inclusive space for everyone.

I’m thrilled to have joined SAS in April this year as a support for the Education Team and I am excited to have moved to the Philanthropy and Partnerships team as the Partnerships Coordinator as a temporary support. I work together with amazing businesses that are striving to have positive impacts on our Oceans. In my free time you are most likely to find me in the surf or on the beach.

Rachel Yates, Senior Communities Manager (Plastic Free Communities)

Pronouns: She/her

I was born overlooking the ocean, it’s lodged in my heart. That and a desire to do what I can to look after the planet and people. I started my SAS journey as a Rep and when the Plastic Free Communities campaign came along it was a perfect fit. After leading Penzance to become the first place to get Plastic Free Communities status in 2017, I joined HQ to manage the national movement.

Sam Blandford – Individual Giving’s Coordinator – She/Her

Hiya! In April 2023 I joined SAS as Individual Giving’s Coordinator, I help to support our amazing fundraising team and the incredible members and donors that help us to continue to do ocean-saving work!

I have always had a deep love and connection to the ocean from spending my life visiting Cornwall whenever I could, now that I am able to live here, and help to protect what I love, I am living the dream!!!

I joined the SAS fundraising team as Community Fundraising Officer in 2021.

My role involves developing opportunities to engage people to fundraise for the ocean, such as our latest Dip A Day campaign we ran in 2022. The ocean has given me so much, and I’m thrilled to work in a role where I can help fight for it.

Hi friends. I’m Sparrow, Head of Happiness at SAS. A very important role. My main job is to provide everyone with lots of love and cuddles, and my fur is incredibly soft – quite therapeutic to stroke, some say. It can be quite a tiring job, so when I’m not busy making everyone happy, you’ll likely find me quietly napping under a desk somewhere.

Stephanie Piper (she/her) – Finance Manager

I joined SAS at the end of 2020. After checking the website over a period of years I was thrilled when finally, a role came up that I was qualified for! It’s a dream to work where you can have a lunch time swim in between managing the day to day finance processes.

I moved to Cornwall 18 years ago so that my children could grow up by the sea. It’s incredibly important to me to protect what we love for future generations.

Having joined SAS in early 2022 as an administrator, I am thrilled to have started off the new year as Partnerships Officer. I work together with our incredible business supporters to maximize our positive impact in the blue spaces that we are all so passionate about. Catch me in the surf or on a hike exploring Cornwall’s beautiful coastlines!

Lucy Luck (She / They) – Campaigns and Policy Coordinator

I joined SAS in April 2024 as Campaigns and Policy Coordinator, my role is to support the delivery of campaigns and activations on all four of our main campaign areas – water quality, the ocean and climate emergency, plastic pollution, and ocean recovery!

I love being outside by the sea as a beachcombing enthusiast and a wild swimmer all year round! I often have a pair of binoculars on me looking out for marine wildlife around the Cornish coast. I also volunteer for multiple marine conservation organisations in the Mounts Bay area and can be found crouched down in rock pools or having a boogie on the beach during a silent disco beach clean!

Chris has more than 25 years PR industry experience, 16 of which were spent at M&C Saatchi where he set up and ran M&C Saatchi PR.

He is currently the Managing Director at award winning independent agency The Academy.

He has been a trustee at SAS for more than 15 years, working with the charity on campaigns, and is a keen surfer.

Lesley has had a varied career, including screen printer, knitwear designer, ghostwriter and seaside landlady.

In Australia in 1982, her 10 month-old daughter was hospitalized with gastro-enteritis from airborne spray from raw sewage discharged at a nearby outfall and took many months to fully recover.

Returning to Cornwall, Lesley nursed family through repeated ear infections and stomach bugs caused by raw sewage in the waters around St Agnes.

In the early days of SAS, Lesley was Honorary Treasurer, becoming a non-executive director then a trustee when the charity was formed.

I joined SAS as a trustee in 2017 and love being involved in a small charity that’s making such a big difference! I live in Marazion in Cornwall (a Plastic Free Community with a Plastic Free School!) and am lucky to be able to spend lots of time in, on and under the ocean with my family. I am a marine scientist and conservationist working for the Zoological Society of London and an Honorary Professor at the University of Exeter (Cornwall campus). I focus on how marine science can enable solutions.

Lucy Siegle is a UK based journalist and broadcaster who specialises in climate and nature. She has contributed internationally to climate and nature protection including through the UN Oceans Dialogue and the COP26 summit.

Lucy is the author of books including Turning the Tide on Plastic: How Humanity (and you) Can Make Our Globe Clean Again and To Die For: Is Fashion Wearing out the World, published

As well as being a trustee for Surfers Against Sewage, Lucy is a member of British Canoeing. She kayaks most days on the non tidal Thames where she lives near Hampton Court, removing waste plastic from the water.

Jen is a Chartered Accountant who started her career with Deloitte and has specialised in charity finance and governance for over twenty five years. She lives in Wimborne in Dorset and is also a Trustee of Dorset Community Foundation, The Labrador Rescue Trust and Dorset Equality Group. Jen swims with East Dorset Open Water Swimming Club at Shore Road Beach in Poole. She represents small charities on the ICAEW Charity Committee and attends the ICAEW South West ESG insight meetings.
